events.description: The Reserve Bank of India kept its repo rate at 5.25% in February 2026.
The Reserve Bank of India implemented a 25-basis-point cut in December.
US 10-year–2-year spread nearing a four-year high amid Fed rate cut expectations.

facts.fact_text: The yield on India’s 10-year G-Sec rose to approximately 6.7%.

evidences.evidence_text: The yield on India’s 10-year G-Sec rose to around 6.7%, recovering from two-week lows

facts.fact_text: The Reserve Bank of India maintained the repo rate at 5.25% in February 2026.

evidences.evidence_text: The Reserve Bank of India kept its repo rate at 5.25% in February 2026

facts.fact_text: The US 10-year–2-year yield spread is at a near four-year high.

evidences.evidence_text: with the 10-year–2-year spread nearing a four-year high

claims.claim_text: Tight domestic liquidity and global rate trends caused investors to seek higher returns.

evidences.evidence_text: tight domestic liquidity and global rate trends pushed investors to demand higher returns

claims.claim_text: The impact of the RBI's rate hold on bond prices was constrained by liquidity pressures.

evidences.evidence_text: While the hold would normally support bond prices, its impact was limited by domestic liquidity pressures and pre-policy market positioning

claims.claim_text: Indian lenders are avoiding government bond purchases due to a deposit shortfall.

evidences.evidence_text: Indian lenders face a deposit shortfall and are reluctant to buy government bonds

claims.claim_text: RBI's foreign exchange interventions have reduced available rupee liquidity.

evidences.evidence_text: as RBI’s FX interventions and liquidity injections have drained rupee funds

evidence.evidence_text: tight domestic liquidity and global rate trends pushed investors to demand higher returns
as RBI’s FX interventions and liquidity injections have drained rupee funds
Additional support came from US Treasury yields
Indian lenders face a deposit shortfall and are reluctant to buy government bonds
